rsbNotes.title: Ps 119
rsbNotes.text:
Ps. 119 As Ps. 117 has the distinction of being the shortest chapter in the Bible, so Ps. 119 is the longest. The psalm is an acrostic of twenty-two stanzas, one for each letter of the Hebrew alphabet. The eight poetic lines of each stanza begin with the same Hebrew letter.

The number eight may be connected with eight Hebrew words that appear throughout the psalm concerning its main theme. The words are translated variously as “law,” “testimonies,” “precepts,” “statutes,” “commandments,” “rules,” and “word.” In five stanzas all eight Hebrew words occur, and every stanza has at least six of the eight.

While the psalmist expresses his love for the law and his desire to obey it, he also recognizes his failures. Elements of lament and petition are intertwined with expressions of confidence and innocence.

The law is a faithful expression of God’s character. God sent His Son to keep the law for us. The law no longer condemns us, setting us free to accept it as our own guide for pleasing the One who died in our place.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 119:153
rsbNotes.text: 119:153 for I do not forget your law. The psalmist expects that God will bless him because he is obedient. Such an attitude could be presumptuous, a sin the Book of Job guards against, but it could also arise from faith.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 119:154
rsbNotes.text: 119:154 Plead my cause. This phrase comes from the courtroom. The psalmist asks the Lord to intercede for him before his enemies.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 119:156
rsbNotes.text: 119:156 Great is your mercy. See Lam. 3:23.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 119:161
rsbNotes.text:
119:161 Princes persecute me. The opposition of princes indicate that the psalmist is probably a powerful person, perhaps the king of Israel.

without cause. See Ps. 38:19.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 119:167
rsbNotes.text: 119:167 I love them exceedingly. Obedience is not an onerous task for the psalmist; he follows God’s law because he wants to.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 119:169
rsbNotes.text: 119:169 give me understanding. This line sums up one of the major themes of the psalm: the desire for insight into God’s will so that the writer may act in obedience.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 119:170
rsbNotes.text: 119:170 deliver me. Another major theme of the psalm is summed up: the psalmist’s need for deliverance.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 119:175
rsbNotes.text: 119:175 Let my soul live. Once again, an indication that the poet was in the midst of trouble at the time he composed his song.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 119:176
rsbNotes.text: 119:176 seek your servant. The psalmist concludes by invoking God as his Shepherd (Ps. 23; John 10); he begs Him to bring him back into the flock.
